Issues.Title: feat(ivy): make Hammer support tree-shakable
Issues.Body:
Currently, it's not possible to tree-shake away the
coordination layer between HammerJS and Angular's
EventManager. This means that you get the HammerJS
support code in your production bundle whether or
not you actually use the library.

This commit removes the Hammer providers from the
default platform_browser providers list and instead
provides them as part of a `HammerModule`. Apps on
Ivy just need to import the `HammerModule` at root
to turn on Hammer support. Otherwise all Hammer code
will tree-shake away. View Engine apps will require
no change.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(ivy): make Hammer support tree-shakable" (#32203)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): reset binding index before executing a template in `refreshView` call
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, the `BINDING_INDEX` of a given lView was reset after processing a template. However change detection can be triggered as a result of View queries processing, thus leading to the subsequent `refreshView` call (and executing a template), which in turn operated with the binding index that was not reset after the previous `refreshView` call. This commit updates the logic to reset binding index before we execute template, so that we always get the right binding index.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): reset binding index before executing a template in `refreshView` call" (#32201)

Issues.Title: feat(core): Introduce TestBed.inject to replace TestBed.get
Issues.Body:
TestBed.get is not type safe, fixing it would be a massive breaking
change. The Angular team has proposed replacing it with TestBed.inject
and deprecate TestBed.get.

Fixes #26491
Fixes #29905

BREAKING CHANGE: Injector.get now accepts abstract classes to return
type-safe values. Previous implementation returned `any` through the
deprecated implementation.

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->
```ts
TestBed.get(ChangeDetectorRef) // returns any
```

Issue Number: #26491, #29905


## What is the new behavior?
```ts
// Now deprecated
TestBed.get(ChangeDetectorRef) // returns any

TestBed.inject(ChangeDetectorRef) // returns ChangeDetectorRef
```


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->

The breaking change affects a feature that has been deprecated since Angular 4.x
`Injector#get()` has 2 signatures:
- Typed signature, accept an `InjectionToken<T>` and a class (`Type<T>`)
- Anything else is also accepted but typed as `any`

The updated Typed signature now also accepts abstract classes (`AbstractType<T>`) which may cause compilation issues to the deprecated use of `any` as it would need to be manually downcasted to the concrete type if needed.


## Other information

Internal doc - [go/testbed.inject](http://go/testbed.inject)

**Note:** I did not update _all_ uses of `TestBed.get` in the Angular codebase to keep this diff small.
I will follow with another CL migrating all `TestBed.get` to `TestBed.inject` if this PR goes through.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(core): Introduce TestBed.inject to replace TestBed.get" (#32200)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove disabled injectable-pipe migration
Issues.Body:
Initially the plan was to have a migration that adds `@Injectable()` to
all pipes in a CLI project so that the pipes can be injected in Ivy
similarly to how it worked in view engine.

Due to the planned refactorings which ensure that `@Directive`, `@Component`
and `@Pipe` also have a factory definition that is picked up by the injector, this
migration is no longer needed for Ivy (FW-1468). Additionally since it is already disabled
(due to 572b54967c969c88c61970650fb857afc1d74f8a) and we have a more generic migration (known as `missing-injectable)`
that could do the same as `injectable-pipe`, we remove the migration from the code-base.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(core): remove disabled injectable-pipe migration" (#32184)

Issues.Title: AOT: Using `import` without saving it in a `loadChildren` key doesn't work
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ## Edit After changing the name of the key (in the object that saves the `() => import(...)` statement) from `module` to `loadChildren`, my code started working, and the bundles worked nicely. This in fact means that, `ngc` only looks for `loadChildren` keys in variables to compile correctly. ## Original bug Using `import` to lazy-load modules removes practically all module code from generated bundle when using `ng build --prod`. ### Is this a regression? Don't know, wrote this code recently starting with latest `@angular/cli`, so didn't test this on older versions. ### Description I'm writing a library to allow `@angular/router` style optional loading of modules, as in: * declare modules to load * each module can have `canActivate` to specify whether they should be loaded or not This works nicely when not building for AOT, but when using AOT, this doesn't work. **The real cause is that, compared to the non-aot build, which produces normal output bundles, the aot build produces practically empty bundles, that aren't really `NgModuleFactory`ies.** For example, lets take `Feature1Module`: * [source code of Feature1Module](https://github.com/gioragutt/lazy-loaded-feature-modules-poc/blob/aot-fixes/src/app/feature1/feature1.module.ts). * [Output without aot](https://pastebin.com/7WXWr3Df) * [Output with aot](https://pastebin.com/FgYTYNV4) * [Output of module when used in routing `loadChildren`](https://pastebin.com/yxETyVhL) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ```bash git clone git@github.com:gioragutt/lazy-loaded-feature-modules-poc.git issue-repro cd issue-repro git checkout aot-fix ng serve --open --prod ``` ## üî• Exception or Error Thrown by [my code](https://github.com/gioragutt/lazy-loaded-feature-modules-poc/blob/aot-fixes/projects/lazy-feature/src/lib/feature-module-loader.service.ts#L37): 


main.24959e29dc0f00a52f9a.js:1 ERROR Error: Module feature1 exported incorrectly. An NgModule or NgModuleFactory should be exported
    at u.project (main.24959e29dc0f00a52f9a.js:1)
    at u._tryNext (main.24959e29dc0f00a52f9a.js:1)

    at s.run (polyfills.5cb1e996b2a376ba4548.js:1)
    at polyfills.5cb1e996b2a376ba4548.js:1

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): handle deep imports that already have an extension
Issues.Body:
**refactor(ngcc): avoid repeated file resolution during dependency scan**

During the recursive processing of dependencies, ngcc resolves the
requested file to an actual location on disk, by testing various
extensions. For recursive calls however, the path is known to have been
resolved in the module resolver. Therefore, it is safe to move the path
resolution to the initial caller into the recursive process.

Note that this is not expected to improve the performance of ngcc, as
the call to `resolveFileWithPostfixes` is known to succeed immediately,
as the provided path is known to exist without needing to add any
postfixes. Furthermore, the FileSystem caches whether files exist, so
the additional check that we used to do was cheap.

---

**fix(ngcc): handle deep imports that already have an extension**

During the dependency analysis phase of ngcc, imports are resolved to
files on disk according to certain module resolution rules. Since module
specifiers are typically missing extensions, or can refer to index.js
barrel files within a directory, the module resolver attempts several
postfixes when searching for a module import on disk. Module  specifiers
that already include an extension, however, would fail to be resolved as
ngcc's module resolver failed to check the location on disk without
adding any postfixes.

Closes #32097
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ngcc): handle deep imports that already have an extension" (#32181)

Issues.Title: Shorthand syntax for `ng-container` and `ng-template`
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for @angular/core ### Description `ng-container` and `ng-template` are incredibly useful tools, but their selectors are extremely verbose when you consider how fundamental they are. ### Describe the solution you'd like A possible solution would be to add a shorthand tag names for these. I propose: `@` for `ng-container` and `#` for `ng-template`. It would turn this contrived example: ``` {{ chapter.name }}
{{ chapter.preview }}
Sign up to read this chapter!
``` into this: ``` <@ *ngIf="book"> <@ *for="let chapter of book.chapters"> {{ chapter.name }} <@ *ngIf="!chapter.locked; else previewLocked">
{{ chapter.preview }}
<#previewLocked>
Sign up to read this chapter!
``` ### Describe alternatives you've considered 1. Writing a preprocessor to do this to my projects. 2. Dealing with the verbosity.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Shorthand syntax for `ng-container` and `ng-template`" (#32191)

Issues.Title: change detection wrong order on child components
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Life cycle and Change detection not running in the correct order for 2 sibling components. ### Is this a regression? Not that I'm aware of. ### Description I have 2 sibling components. The first hosts a template via ngTemplateOutlet The 2nd has the template as part of its view to be used by its sibling. The parent gets the template from the 2nd child and passes it to the first child. It works fine if the template that we're getting from the 2nd child gets passed to the 1st child in the first cycle. However, if we need a 2nd cycle to get the template like the following code it doesn't work. 

  ngAfterViewInit() {
    setTimeout(() => {
      this.templates = this.templateQuery.map( c => c.template );
      this.cdr.markForCheck();
    }, 0);
  }
Doing it in the set timeout is necessary otherwise you may get a ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError. The input bindings on the inner template are always one cycle behind the parent component. The issue appears to be that the order that angular runs the life cycle hooks is not the same in the 1st case as in the 2nd. In the first case. The content is checked on the template component before the host component. So the change is detected and passed through to the host component. However in the 2nd case Change detection first runs on the host component and nothing changed yet so the view doesn't update. Then it's run on the template component, but it's already too late for the host component. So it's not picked up till the next cycle. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction click the button and notice the inner template in the broken section is one step behind. https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-djxc1a ## üî• Exception or Error The view isn't updated correctly. The child is one cycle behind the parent. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Node: 12.6.0

Issues.Title: ng serve claims port is in use when it isn't.
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Unsure ### Description Despite the fact that it's given a free port, ng serve refuses to run on any port, saying "Port XXXX is already in use. Use '--port' to specify a different port." where XXXX is the port number. It's not an issue of the port being in use by another process, because I used the same port number to launch other applications, like React, and those worked fine. It is rejecting any port number I give it with the same error. I have two angular applications, one works fine, the other does not. Both are in the same directory, but should not be interfering with each other Directory tree: udemyangular --my-first-app --prnnppr-app First one won't run, second one does. my-first-app is nothing more than the scaffold from ng new, and prnnppr-app is just a starter project for work with a few custom components, I have otherwise not touched .angular.json, or package.json or any of the other config files. I've also deleted and regenerated my-first-app and got the same result. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create two angular applications in the same directory, run ng serve in both of them. Theoretically they should both run fine (provided of course they're given different ports.) ## üî• Exception or Error 

Port 3000 is already in use. Use '--port' to specify a different port.
## üåç Your Environment 

OS: darwin x64
Angular: 6.1.10
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

Issues.Title: @ngtools/webpack HMR compilation errors ignored
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

not using angular cli, but @ngtools/webpack

### Is this a regression?

Dont know if this ever worked with `@ngtools/webpack` because i havent been using it during development before.

### Description

When you create compilation error in project, like you add some unused import, compilation throws error in console, but this error is not displayed in `WebpackNotifierPlugin` nor in browser through `HMR`. When you use `awesome-typescript-loader` it works correctly. 

What is even weirder is that if you stop compilation process and run it again, error is thrown correctly everywhere, only during `HMR` change it is not handled correctly. 

If you fix initial problem and `HMR` is running you will get error 
> from the TypeScript compilation. Please make sure it is in your tsconfig via the 'files' or 'include' property.

and you have to restart `npm start` command. All three mentioned things are slowing development with `@ngtools/webpack` compared to `awesome-typescript-loader`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

download this https://github.com/kukjevov/ngtools-error

**#1**

> `git clone https://github.com/kukjevov/ngtools-error`
> `cd ngtools-error`
> `npm install`
> `npm start`
> open in browser `http://localhost:8888
> add `ChangeDetectorRef` into `navigation.component.ts` into import statement
> save file
> you can see error in system console, but no error in browser, nor in WebpackNotifierWindow

**#2**

> stop `npm start`
> run `npm start` again
> you will see error in system notification window
> refresh browser `http://localhost:8888`
> you will see also in browser

**#3**

> open `navigation.component.ts` and remove unused `ChangeDetectorRef` from import statement
> save file
> you can see error in system console, this errors dissapears after you restart `npm start`

## üî• Exception or Error

See minimal reproduction part

## üåç Your Environment

- angular: 9.0.0-next.2
- @ngtools/webpack: 8.3.0-rc.0
- node: 10.16.0
- npm: 6.9.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "@ngtools/webpack HMR compilation errors ignored" (#15372)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): expose webpack-dev-server's allowedHosts option
Issues.Body:
This PR adds `allowedHosts` as option and passes it along to the dev server. Issue #13656 describes a use-case for this. My use-case is slightly different, as I'm working on a multi-tenant application that derives the tenant from the host name. Having access to `allowedHosts` makes it possible to define multiple hosts pointing to 127.0.0.1 and using them to access the dev server (during development).

A test was added, but I'm not entirely happy with the end result. The `beforeEach` and `afterEach` are duplicate with `public-host_spec_large.ts` (although more spec files have the exact same code). It might also be better to combine it with the public-host spec file, as some test cases in there (no options specified, or with `disableHostCheck`) also apply to the `allowedHosts` option.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): expose webpack-dev-server's allowedHosts option" (#15366)

Issues.Title: ng upgrade V7->V8: missing peer dependency error for project including @ngtools/webpack
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? n/a Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... When attempting to upgrade a project from V7 to V8, if the project includes '@ngtools/webpack' but not the peer dependency 'webpack' the upgrade fails. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create a new project Angular V7 project using 'ngNew' 2. Add '@ngtools/webpack' using 'npm install @ngtools/webpack' 3. Attempt to update the project using 'ng update @angular/cli @angular/core'. You will get an error: Package "@ngtools/webpack" has an incompatible peer dependency to "typescript" (requires ">=2.4.0 < 3.3", would install "3.5.3"). 4. So add @ngtools/webpack to the command line (i.e.) ng update @angular/cli @angular/core @ngtools/webpack 5. You will get the error: Package "@ngtools/webpack" has a missing peer dependency of "webpack" @ "^4.0.0". Adding webpack using 'npm install webpack' before upgrading causes the upgrade to be successful. Removing 'webpack' using 'npm uninstall webpack' after the upgrade removes it from the project.json and node_modules and causes ng serve to show the following error: An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot find module 'webpack' Note also that 'webpack' appears to be in the node_modules by default even if not listed explicitly in the package.json (unless removed as described above in which case npm install does not seem to restore it). ## üî• Exception or Error 



Package "@ngtools/webpack" has a missing peer dependency of "webpack" @ "^4.0.0".
## üåç Your Environment 




Before upgrade:

Angular CLI: 7.3.9
Node: 10.16.3
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 7.2.15
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.13.9
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.13.9
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.13.9
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.13.9
@angular-devkit/core              7.3.9
@angular-devkit/schematics        7.3.9
@angular/cli                      7.3.9
@ngtools/webpack                  7.3.9
@schematics/angular               7.3.9
@schematics/update                0.13.9
rxjs                              6.3.3
typescript                        3.2.4
webpack                           4.29.0

After upgrade (webpack removed)
Angular CLI: 8.2.2
Node: 10.16.3
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.2.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.802.2
@angular-devkit/core              8.2.2
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.2.2
@ngtools/webpack                  8.2.2
@schematics/angular               8.2.2
@schematics/update                0.802.2
rxjs                              6.5.2
typescript                        3.5.3
**Anything else relevant?** n/a This is Windows 10 Using the CLI from a Powershell Window (Non-admin).

Issues.Title: Incorrect path to Angular library
Issues.Body:
I am using Angular library and have the following folder structure:
```
coollibrary
  - components
    - my.component.ts
  - services
    - my.service.ts
public_api.ts
```
In public_api, I export the component and service and make the library build.
After that I can import the necessary things in my project using
```
import { MyComponent } from 'coollibrary';
```
but I can not use the following path:
```
import { MyComponent  } from 'coollibrary/components'
```
Can I use correct path?

Issues.Title: CLI File Naming Options
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
angular CLI


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
currently when a component is generated it might be called x.component.ts and a service like y.service.ts

This has a few negative effects in my book:
1 - sorting by name does not group components and services together.
2 - Hungarian-like naming becomes awkward, eg `ServiceAnalyticsService`. Service is prepended in the hungarian-like system I like, but it also has to be appended to comply with angular convention.
3 - it doesn't seem possible to programmatically or humanly know whether a folder under app refers to a component, service, module...by looking at the folder name when generating a non-flat entity.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
1 - An option to have the files generated with flipped naming like component.x.ts and service.y.ts
2 - A different option to allow type to be added to the folder name without redundancy. So normal mode is `x-component/x.component.ts` and flipped is `component-x/component.x.ts`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
I'm personally OK with the redundant naming but my team isn't. So a key workaround would be having a component called ComponentThingComponent or ServiceSomeService.


ref: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/32158
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CLI File Naming Options" (#15351)

##### Highlights

-   The `MatNavTabBar` now support tab pagination, a long-requested feature.
-   `CdkDrag` now supports scrolling the viewport when an item is dragged near the edge.

-   **drag-drop:** return up-to-date position if getFreeDragPosition is called while dragging ([#​16464](https://togithub.com/angular/components/issues/16464)) ([1540391](https://togithub.com/angular/components/commit/1540391))
-   **expansion:** incorrect margin for "before" indicator when expanded ([#​16420](https://togithub.com/angular/components/issues/16420)) ([98a231d](https://togithub.com/angular/components/commit/98a231d))
-   **menu:** keyboard controls not respecting DOM order when items are added at a later point ([#​11720](https://togithub.com/angular/components/issues/11720)) ([49e8c59](https://togithub.com/angular/components/commit/49e8c59)), closes [#​11652](https://togithub.com/angular/components/issues/11652)
-   **overlay:** incorrectly calculating position when page is scrolled horizontally and overlay is anchored to the right ([#​16235](https://togithub.com/angular/components/issues/16235)) ([f61730a](https://togithub.com/angular/components/commit/f61730a)), closes [#​16009](https://togithub.com/angular/components/issues/16009)
-   **overlay:** OverlayKeyboardDispatcher (used in dialog and overlay
      and available in the CDK) now listens on bubbling/propagation phase
      instead of capture phase. This means that overlay keydown handlers
      are now called after any applicable handlers inside of an overlay,
      and it respects any stopPropagation() calls from inside the overlay.

Issues.Title: build: switch test targets to karma_web_test_suite
Issues.Body:
Switches all `ts_web_test_suite` targets to the new
`karma_web_test_suite` rule. `ts_web_test_suite` is
based on the `karma_web_test_suite` rule but does not
allow developers to have a custom karma configuration.

In order to be able to provide a custom karma configuration
for setting up Saucelabs and Browserstack, we switch all
targets over to the `karma_web_test_suite` rule.

See: https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_typescript/pull/363.

@josephperrott I don't think we want to provide a custom karma configuration for all targets right now. Only the target that runs on Saucelabs should provide the custom karma configuration. We prospectively will have targets that combine multiple tests to avoid rate and browser limits.

Ideally even then, we would not need to specify a custom karma configuration as the default karma configuration for Bazel has an integrated mechanism for using saucelabs. see:

https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/blob/master/packages/karma/src/karma.conf.js#L311
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: switch test targets to karma_web_test_suite" (#16818)

Issues.Title: build: remove workaround for ivy test job
Issues.Body:
We currently have a workaround in the `ivy_test` job
in place because initially when we created the job, ngcc
did not support the `umd` format. This is now fixed and
we should be able to use ngcc to make the Angular packages
compatible with ngtsc.

We don't want to continue pulling a specific version from the
github build repositories, but rather want to test against the
current ivy version of the installed angular packages.

Testing against snapshots is covered by the `ivy_snapshot_test` job.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: remove workaround for ivy test job" (#16817)

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/chips): high contrast mode fixes
Issues.Body:
Fixes the following issues with the MDC-based chips in high contrast mode:
* Chips blending in with the background because they don't have an outline or a border.
* No focus indication being visible.
* Chips being hidden completely on hover because we were using an RGBA overlay.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental/chips): high contrast mode fixes" (#16811)

Issues.Title: fix(tabs): tabs with background overriding ripple color for all descendants
Issues.Body: When a tab group has a background color we need to change its ripple color so it doesn't blend in with the background, however the current selector is too broad which means that it also targets all the ripples inside the tabs content. These changes narrow down the selector to avoid the issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(tabs): tabs with background overriding ripple color for all descendants" (#16810)

Issues.Title: fix(stepper): remove tabindex from content
Issues.Body:
A while ago in #14892 we added a `tabindex` to the content of the current step based on a recommendation from W3C a11y guidelines, however since then we consulted with the a11y team and it looks like adding the `tabindex` there isn't the best approach.

Fixes #16692.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(stepper): remove tabindex from content" (#16809)

Issues.Body: Currently the margins for buttons inside the `mat-action-row` is only set up for `mat-button`, however we have other variants like raised and stroked buttons which haven't been accounted for.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(expansion): not adding margin for all button types" (#16806)

Issues.Title: prototype(tabs): create prototype tabs based on MDC web
Issues.Body:
Adds an implementation of the Angular Material tabs that is based on MDC web. The API is exactly the same, except for a couple of differences:

1. The ink bar has been switched to use MDC's `tab-indicator`. As such the styling and the animation are slightly different.
2. Previously `MatTabLink` used to be a `Directive`, however now it's a `Component`, because we need some extra markup around the content.

**Note:** this is **not** merge safe, because I had to move a few things around in the current tabs module.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "prototype(tabs): create prototype tabs based on MDC web" (#16805)

Issues.Title: feat(google-maps): Add methods and event handling to Google Map
Issues.Body:
Add support for Google Maps event handlers, properties, and methods to
the Google Map component, including click handlers, methods to pan with
the map and access to the controls and data properties.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(google-maps): Add methods and event handling to Google Map" (#16804)

Issues.Title: Better error reporting for mat-form-field
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

It looks as if `mat-form-field` cannot be used without `MatInputModule`, at least in the context of the API documentation.  [We could easily end up with this scenario](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57522683/error-error-mat-form-field-must-contain-a-matformfieldcontrol-while-using-api-d/57522750#57522750).

Provide a brief summary of the feature you would like to see.
Better error reporting to address this:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57522683/error-error-mat-form-field-must-contain-a-matformfieldcontrol-while-using-api-d/57522750#57522750

#### Use Case

Describe the use case(s) that the proposed feature would enable.
Ideally the error would say that we also need to import the `MatInputModule`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Better error reporting for mat-form-field" (#16797)

Issues.Title: prototype(slider): create prototype slider based on MDC web
Issues.Body:
Creates a prototype of `mat-slider` that uses MDC web. The feature comparison document has been filled.

A list of notable bugs in the MDC foundation right now:

* input event not rounded before comparing (causing multiple `input` events; workaround applied)
* Thumb label not updating if value changes programmatically (workaround applied)
* Slider updates value with right mouse events
* change event always fired on mouse up or keydown
* slider measurements and ticks only updated on init and "resize" event
  * standard Angular Material slider did this on `mouseenter`.
* Vertical alignment (incorrect calculations; currently shifted down 2px of baseline)

Notable feature differences:

* Visually sliders look totally different to our current implementation
* Vertical sliders are not supported (yet?)
* Sliders do not support decimal steps.
* Sliders cannot be inverted (no support in the foundation)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "prototype(slider): create prototype slider based on MDC web" (#16795)

Issues.Title: mat-select not closing when clicking in another container
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. implement mat-select
2. open it
3. click in another container which is not the parent
 
#### Expected Behavior

Should close the options list


#### Actual Behavior

does not close the options list


#### Environment

- Angular: 7.3.7
- CDK/Material: 7.3.7
- Browser(s): all
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "mat-select not closing when clicking in another container" (#16793)
